purpose.p: This part of ISO 10303 specifies an application module for the representation of catalogue data. A catalogue record for an item consists of the identification of the class to which an item belongs, and a set of "property-value pairs". A property value may be either a string, an enumeration value (an externally defined string), a currency amount, or a measurement. Cataloguing concepts are defined in an external dictionary and referenced via globally unique identifiers. The following are considered cataloguing concepts:

ul.li: qualifier of measure (e.g., minimum, maximum, nominal);

purpose.note: For compatibility with existing STEP implementations, SI units represented in the customary manner and are not referenced to an external dictionary. Since SI units are standardized and well-known, an explicit reference is not considered necessary.

For compatibility with existing STEP implementations, the data type of a property value (typically captured as a representation_item), is not referenced to an external dictionary. Since a small, well-known set of data types is being used, an explicit reference is not considered necessary.

inscope.li: representation of a catalogue data set;
representation of the class to which an item belongs;
representation of simple property values, including enumerated, string, currency, and measure;
representation of units of measure for measure property values;
representation of qualifiers for measure property values;
association of property values to specific features of a product;
representation of external identifiers for concepts class, property, feature, representation, unit of measure, qualifier of measure, enumeration value and currency.

outscope.li: representation of a dictionary containing definitions for concepts class, property, feature, representation, unit of measure, qualifier of measure, enumeration value and currency referenced from this module;
the schema and format for identifiers used to reference externally defined concepts;
the resolution mechanism for identifiers used to reference externally defined concepts.
